entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - Architecture and Lessons-Learned
entry.content:
Thanks for sharing your experience, and for the very neat blog!
What I like spaces for, especially segregating them by SAP modules, when it's the primary Source System in a 2-3 tier landscape:
> They force developers to think where to put the objects and who takes the ownership.
> The lineage visibility is much more clear.
> They force developers to analyse dependencies between transport packages and communicate.
> Segregation of storage, compute, connections.
> Service approach, isolation, authorizations.
> Avoidance of monolithic mess and potential duplication.
What I don't like:
< Not being able to easily join cross-space views from the Database Explorer.
< Maintenance. 

I have some thoughts about putting Fact Views in the reporting layer and not propagation too, but that maybe for another time.

Cheers!

entry.title: Re: Support for Base64-Encoded Fingerprints in SFTP Adapter
entry.content:
@CCSAPCEPSA 

If you are on SP33 Patch 0 or Patch 1, you must configure the fingerprint in Base64 format (e.g., SHA256:xxxxxx…) for the scenario to work, since the server provides the fingerprint in this format. However, any existing scenarios with fingerprints configured in hexadecimal format will fail during fingerprint validation.

The enhancement described in SAP Note 3652688 is available starting from SP33 Patch 2. With this change, fingerprints configured in hexadecimal format (with or without MD5/SHA1 prefix) will work without issues. If you want to use Base64 format fingerprints, you must explicitly configure them in the channel and set the parameter useBase64Fingerprint to true.

entry.title: Re: Exporting SAP Tables with SLT to MS-SQL Server or AWS official documentation

To replicate into DB not supported by SAP you need to use SLT SDK where implement own logic.  See https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/2652704
If you would like to replicate data into MS SQL Server you can use standard implementation delivered with SLT ADDON. You nee to configure DB connection to MSSQL and in SLT create configuration choosing this DB connection as target.

entry.title: Re: Use case of MMRV
entry.content:
Hello @KARTHIK-G 

That's right - MMRV switches on/off postings to a previous period:

A typical business case of such backpostings is that not all MM postings are entered into the system in real time. For instance receipts from production may be posted in real time, they might be automatically posted by a MES system. Therefore production needs a new period opened at the very beginning of a month. However other postings might be entered with a delay, for instance office supplies receipts might be posted only during working days, not on weekends.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

Please refer to KBA 3310759 - Revised Authorization Concept for SAP Readiness Check 

To access SAP Readiness Check on SAP for Me [ https://me.sap.com/readinesscheck ], S-user need below authorizations:

entry.title: Re: S4HC Public Cloud Eclipse created CDS and AMDP
entry.content:
I have now got this working.  The error that I first received was a Red Herring 🦐  - it led me down a rabbit hole 🐰 that I did not need to enter.😫  It said The client handling annotation was wrong...   well that was only part of the problem. ⛳

In S/4HANA Public Cloud there are restrictions - mainly on that Blog example I found (I now know it is only suits on-premise - a very important point) it is that ACDOCA is not a table that can be selected directly in public cloud at least- another related CDS in S/4 is to be found - I used I_JournalEntryItem.  At least in my version it is also quite particular about client/mandt, declarations of parameter types, database function select of data using the parameters,API state contracts.

Here is what I did

Define view entity ZVE_JournalData - and this has the API State Contract C1: Use System-Internally set.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'CDS ViewEntityon I_JOURNALENTRYITEMCUBE'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZVE_JournalData 
  with parameters

    p_bukrs : abap.char(4), //MAYBE ALSO DO NOT USE TYPE BUKRS here either - as class method gets error SQLSCRIPT message: invalid identifier: parameterized sql view ZVE_JOURNALDATA without input arguments

    p_gjahr : abap.char(4) //MAYBE ALSO DO NOT USE TYPE gjahr here either
    
as select from I_JournalEntryItem as J
{

  J.Ledger              as RLDNR,

  J.CompanyCode         as RBUKRS,

  J.FiscalYear          as GJAHR,

  J.AccountingDocument  as BELNR    
}
where

  J.CompanyCode = $parameters.p_bukrs

  and J.FiscalYear = $parameters.p_gjahr;

Define table function Z_JOURNAL_DATA

@EndUserText.label: 'Journal Data'


@ClientHandling.algorithm: #SESSION_VARIABLE //the client_element_name column is filled from the session client (sy-mandt).
@ClientHandling.type: #CLIENT_DEPENDENT
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED // No auth checks (default)

define table function Z_JOURNAL_DATA
with parameters 
     i_RBUKRS  : abap.char( 4 ), //do not use type BUKRS as class gets error The object DTEL BUKRS must not be used here, because it is not released for usage in AMDP methods.
     i_GJAHR   : abap.char(4) ////do not use type GJAHR as class gets error The object DTEL GJAHR must not be used here, because it is not released for usage in AMDP methods.
    
returns {
    rclnt :mandt; //Z_JOURNAL_DATA is marked as client-specific so this is NEEDED 
    
    RLDNR : fins_ledger; 
    RBUKRS: bukrs; 
    GJAHR : gjahr; 
    BELNR : belnr_d; 
  
}

implemented by method zcl_acc_je_dat=>GET_JE_DATA;

Define the AMDP Class zcl_acc_je_dat METHOD GET_JE_DATA BY DATABASE FUNCTION

I am not entirely happy with the SELECT returning that CLIENT but was the only way I could get it to work.

CLASS zcl_acc_je_dat DEFINITION PUBLIC.
PUBLIC SECTION.

INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    CLASS-METHODS  GET_JE_DATA
 FOR TABLE FUNCTION Z_JOURNAL_DATA.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_acc_je_dat IMPLEMENTATION.
METHOD GET_JE_DATA BY DATABASE FUNCTION FOR HDB LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY USING ZVE_JOURNALDATA.

RETURN SELECT
                  SESSION_CONTEXT('CLIENT') as rclnt,
                  rldnr,
                  rbukrs,
                  gjahr,
                  belnr
           FROM ZVE_JOURNALDATA( p_bukrs => :i_rbukrs, p_gjahr => :i_gjahr );

ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

The data can be previewed in Eclipse when I connect to my data client 100 (objects developed in my dev client 080)

 

I also wanted to create in my S/4 public cloud application 🏢 a Custom CDS View

For that I have also a define view entity ZVE_Z_JOURNAL_DATA.  This also needed the API State System-Internally contract C1 set

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'CDS View on TableFunction.For S4 CustCDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZVE_Z_JOURNAL_DATA
  with parameters
    p_bukrs : bukrs,
    p_gjahr : gjahr

  as select from Z_JOURNAL_DATA (
                     i_RBUKRS: $parameters.p_bukrs,
                     i_GJAHR : $parameters.p_gjahr
                   ) as d
{
  key d.BELNR,
      d.RLDNR,
      d.RBUKRS,
      d.GJAHR

}

and so my S/4 application the Custom CDS View was created on that view entity.  Seen displayed here with the parameters entered

entry.content: I have the same issue java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: No signature of method: java.lang.String.call() is applicable for argument types: any(), wait(long), any(groovy.lang.Closure), take(int) with my groovy script import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message import groovy.xml.MarkupBuilder import groovy.util.XmlSlurper def Message processData(Message message) { // Country → countryKey_code and currency_code mapping def countryMap = [ "Romania" : [key: "RO", currency: "RON"], "USA" : [key: "US", currency: "USD"], "Canada" : [key: "CA", currency: "CAD"], "Germany" : [key: "DE", currency: "EUR"], "United Kingdom": [key: "GB", currency: "GBP"] ] // Retrieve orgs def matchedOrgs = message.getProperty("MatchedOrgs") ?: [] def missingAddresses = message.getProperty("MissingAddresses") ?: [] // Initialize list of addresses def aggregatedAddresses = [] def sapAddressList = message.getProperty("SapAddressList") ?: [] // Process missing addresses from incoming XML if (!missingAddresses.isEmpty()) { def aggregatorBody = message.getBody(String) if (aggregatorBody) { def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(aggregatorBody) aggregatedAddresses = xml.AddressResponse.collect { addr -> [ ID : addr.ID.text(), address : addr.address.text(), street : addr.street.text(), number : addr.houseNumber.text(), city : addr.city.text(), country : addr.country.text(), countryKey_code: addr.countryKeyCode.text() ] } } } // Merge SAP + newly created addresses (unique by ID) def allAddresses = (sapAddressList + aggregatedAddresses).unique { it.ID } message.setProperty("AggregatedAddresses", aggregatedAddresses) message.setProperty("AllAddresses", allAddresses) // Combine matched and missing orgs into allOrgs def allOrgs = [] // Add matched orgs matchedOrgs.each { org -> allOrgs << [ Name : org.Name ?: "", Street : org.Street ?: "", Number : org.Number ?: "", City : org.City ?: "", Country : org.Country ?: "", addressID_ID : org.addressID_ID ?: "", address : org.address ?: "${org.Street ?: ""} ${org.City ?: ""} ${org.Country ?: ""} ${org.Number ?: ""}".trim() ] } // Add missing addresses missingAddresses.each { org -> def addr = aggregatedAddresses.find { it.street.equalsIgnoreCase(org.Street ?: "") && it.city.equalsIgnoreCase(org.City ?: "") && it.country.equalsIgnoreCase(org.Country ?: "") && ((it.number ?: "") == (org.Number ?: "")) } allOrgs << [ Name : org.Name ?: "", Street : org.Street ?: "", Number : org.Number ?: "", City : org.City ?: "", Country : org.Country ?: "", addressID_ID : addr?.ID ?: "", address : addr?.address ?: "${org.Street ?: ""} ${org.City ?: ""} ${org.Country ?: ""} ${org.Number ?: ""}".trim(), countryKey_code: addr?.countryKey_code ?: "" ] } // Generate unique 4-character company codes def usedCodes = [:].withDefault { 0 } def writer = new StringWriter() def xmlBuilder = new MarkupBuilder(writer) def correlationId = java.util.UUID.randomUUID().toString() message.setProperty("ammsOrgId", correlationId) message.setProperty("expectedCompanyCodeCount", allOrgs.size()) xmlBuilder.Organisations { allOrgs.each { org -> // Clean organization name def cleanName = (org.Name ?: "ORG").replaceAll("\\s","").toUpperCase() def baseCode = cleanName.take(4) // Ensure unique code def count = usedCodes[baseCode] def companyCode = count == 0 ? baseCode : baseCode.take(Math.max(0, 4 - count.toString().length())) + count.toString() usedCodes[baseCode] = count + 1 // Country & currency info def countryInfo = countryMap[org.Country] ?: [key: "", currency: "EUR"] // Build Organisation node safely using mkp.yield Organisation(ammsOrgId: correlationId) { companyCode { mkp.yield companyCode } companyCodeName { mkp.yield (org.Name ?: "") } countryKey_code { mkp.yield (org.countryKey_code ?: countryInfo.key) } currency_code { mkp.yield countryInfo.currency } addressID_ID { mkp.yield (org.addressID_ID ?: "") } address { mkp.yield (org.address ?: "${org.Street ?: ""} ${org.City ?: ""} ${org.Country ?: ""} ${org.Number ?: ""}".trim()) } } } } message.setBody(writer.toString()) // Logging def log = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message) if (log) { log.addAttachmentAsString("SAP_Addresses", sapAddressList.toString(), "application/json") log.addAttachmentAsString("NewlyCreated_Addresses", aggregatedAddresses.toString(), "application/json") log.addAttachmentAsString("AllAddresses", allAddresses.toString(), "application/json") log.addAttachmentAsString("Org_XML_for_Splitter", writer.toString(), "application/xml") log.addAttachmentAsString("AMMS_ammsOrgId", correlationId.toString(), "text/plain") log.addAttachmentAsString("expectedCompanyCodeCount", allOrgs.size().toString(), "text/plain") } return message }

entry.title: Duration Replication for Professional Services Project between S4HC and RM
entry.content:
Here are the documents we have to explain how duration replication works for Project Services Projects:

  1. Help document: Delta Replication for Professional Services Projects
  2. KBA: 3603920 - Resource request period remains unchanged after extending the project period in S4HC.

Despite these documents, several customers have raised questions about this functionality. To address this, I ran tests in my internal system and compiled the behaviors with sample scenarios. I hope this provides a clearer understanding.

Scenario 1: When extending the duration, the changes will not be reflected in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025
Resource request time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025

New work package time period: 18.08.2025-17.10.2025
New resource request time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025

Scenario 2: When the duration is shortened, the changes will be reflected in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.08.2025-30.09.2025
Resource request time period: 01.08.2025-30.09.2025

New work package time period: 15.08.2025-15.09.2025
New resource request time period: 15.08.2025-15.09.2025

Scenario 3: When the new duration lies entirely outside the previous duration, the changes will be reflected in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025
Resource request time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025

New work package time period: 25.08.2025-31.08.2025
New resource request time period: 25.08.2025-31.08.2025

Scenario 4: When the new duration overlaps with the previous duration, the overlapping time will be updated in in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.08.2025-30.08.2025
Resource request time period: 01.08.2025-30.08.2025

New work package time period: 26.08.2025-22.09.2025
New resource request time period: 26.08.2025-30.08.2025

entry.title: Re: ECC6 upgrade operating system and database
entry.content:
Hi,

Whether a specific Microsoft Windows Server OS version can be 'in-place' upgraded to an higher OS version is and issue which depends on Microsoft guidelines.
OS 'in-place' upgrade is not valid for all Microsoft OS versions, so I recommend you ask your Microsoft OS partner whether the 'Microsoft OS in-place' upgrade method is valid for achieving OS upgrade from Windows Server OS 2012/2012R2 to 2019 or 2022 versions or not.

For more information see the Microsoft documentation below:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/get-started/upgrade-overview

Regards,
Riccardo

entry.title: SAP MaxAttention Forum – São Paulo
entry.content:

entry.title: Workforce Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP´s ready-to-run public Cloud ERP software solution. SAP S/4HANS Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem – customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

Managing a skilled workforce efficiently is paramount for any growing organization. With the release 2508 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, businesses are empowered with robust HR connectivity options, which streamline workforce management activities. This article provides guidance on handling workforce data, work agreements, and user management using various technical integration options.

In traditional Identity Management (IDM) scenarios, HR systems usually take the lead in managing worker data and work agreements. Business user data might be managed directly in an IDM system or integrated via an HR system. The culmination of these processes sees the provisioning of worker data, work agreements, and business user data into the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant through effective HR and IDM integration. Successful workforce management in this landscape hinges on strategic decisions about data creation through HR or IDM integration, based on which system leads.

 

Results: Realizing Workforce Management Scenarios


Imagine a scenario where SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is integrated with both the SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (using SAP Master Data Integration for HR) and an external IDM system via SOAP-based integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services. Here, aligning IDM integration as the leading choice brings forth several advantages.

 

Define Workforce Management System and Choose an Integration Option

  • IDM Integration Leads: Creating business user and worker data first allows users to access the system and perform tasks without needing pre-established work agreements.
  • HR Integration Leads: Worker data and work agreements are provisioned first, followed by business user creation, ensuring structured data flow.

To configure your scenario, access SAP Central Business Configuration for your specific tenant, locate the Define Workforce Management Scenario (106757) activity, and select your desired option: IDM or HR integration. Be sure to confirm data consistency across systems before switching options.

 

Flexible Data Management

With the integration setup, you can create worker and business user data within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition through the integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services or manually via the Manage Workforce or Maintain Business Users apps. However, once data is created through integration, it cannot be modified directly in these apps. The Entry Source field denotes where data can be edited and its origin. Refer to the Entry Source documentation for further information. If establishing a work agreement through HR integration precedes the creation of a worker record, an error will occur.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers businesses with flexible HR connectivity options for workforce management. By carefully selecting and implementing integration strategies, organizations can achieve efficient operations and seamless data management, essential for navigating the complex terrain of modern business environments. Choose the path that aligns best with your operational needs, ensuring a smooth and effective workforce management experience.

 

📽️ Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series! 

From July 21 to July 25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for 21 topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand–anywhere, anytime.

entry.title: Re: Difference between TYPE and LIKE in ABAP – When to us...
entry.content:
Just for your information: If you are new to SAP ABAP or the SAP ecosystem, it is highly recommended to first refer to the official SAP documentation: SAP ABAP Documentation. Before posting questions, please also try searching on Google, the SAP Community, or even tools like ChatGPT, as many answers are already available. This helps you learn faster and ensures questions are more focused.

However, please answer below.

1.  TYPE 

Declare a variable based on a data type (built-in or DDIC type). 

Syntax:

DATA var TYPE abap_type [LENGTH len] [DECIMALS dec] [VALUE val] [READ-ONLY].

Eg:

 

DATA text TYPE string VALUE 'Text'.
DATA count TYPE i VALUE 1.
DATA price TYPE p LENGTH 8 DECIMALS 2 VALUE '1.99'.

2 LIKE  

Declare a variable based on another variable or table/field.

  • LIKE copies the type and attributes of another variable or data object.

  • Useful to create new variables similar to existing ones.

Syntax:

 

DATA var LIKE existing_var_or_field [VALUE val] [READ-ONLY].

Eg:

DATA wa TYPE scarr. " Work area based on DDIC table SCARR
SELECT SINGLE * FROM scarr INTO @wa WHERE carrid = 'BA'.
DATA buffer LIKE wa. " Another variable with same type as wa buffer = wa.

Comparison 

Feature TYPE LIKE
Refers toType definition (DDIC or ABAP)Existing variable/field
Updates if DDIC changesYesOnly if referencing the field
Recommended forIn most cases, future-proofCopying existing variables
ExampleDATA lv_value TYPE i.DATA lv_temp LIKE lv_value.

Note:

Always use TYPE for work areas of tables (from DDIC)

Try to avoid LIKE as much as possible 

Eg:

DATA gt_scarr TYPE TABLE OF scarr. " Correct
DATA wa_scarr LIKE LINE OF gt_scarr. " Work area based on table

entry.title: Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in 3-system landscape.
entry.content:
Embarking on the 3-System Landscape (SL) journey in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can be overwhelming. A newly provisioned test tenant may not operate efficiently unless it contains sufficient known data to support you best with testing and validations. 

To address this challenge and accelerate test tenant readiness, SAP has introduced two strategic options, namely TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH. These features are designed to accelerate tenant readiness by simplify data handling and thereby enhancing overall system efficiency. 

In this blog, we’ll take a high-level look at the 3-SL and explore how TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH facilitate to a smoother, faster, and reliable test environment setup. 

 

3-SL  

As part of your strategic transformation, you are planning to migrate from a 2-SL to a 3-SL in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This transition is aimed at enhancing system governance, improving testing capabilities, and enabling a clear change management process. Before diving into the data migration services, let’s examine the landscape differences between the current 2-SL setup and the target 3-SL setup to understand the value and impact of this shift.  

 As part of the 3-SL conversion in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a new test tenant is introduced to support robust validation and quality assurance. However, at the time of conversion, this tenant is provisioned as an empty tenant, with no data (transactional or master data) available. To make this test tenant fully functional and efficient, it must be filled with the essential fuel that drives all meaningful testing, which is nothing but valid data. 

As the saying goes, “Data is the new fuel” and without it, even the most advanced SL cannot deliver value to its fullest. Populating the test tenant with relevant, valid, and consistent data is critical to make the test tenant valuable and ensure a smooth transition to production tenants. 

Now that we understand the importance of data in powering the test tenant, the next step is to determine how to introduce this data effectively into test tenants.

 

Manual Data Uploads: A Time-Consuming Process 

While manual data uploads are technically possible using SAP Fiori apps, templates, or others. but they involve significant drawbacks: 

  • High Effort: Manually preparing valid data and uploading data comes at the cost of extensive time and resources.  
  • Cumbersome Process: This process itself will be complex and challenging as multiple tools and formats need to be used and the complexity increases with large data volumes. 
  • Delayed Availability: Test tenant will not be available for business use until the manual data upload is completed, there by blocking the testing activities for the released objects.

We have seen that, manual data entry is not ideal for large volume of data upload and accelerating tenant readiness. 

 

Embracing Automation: Smarter Ways to Populate Your Test Tenant 

We’re in the era of automation and manual data entry is no longer a viable option for efficient system setup. If you already have rich, validated data in your customizing tenant and production tenant, the question becomes: 
How can you use this data to build a clean, depersonalized, and test-ready environment in your new test tenant. To address this common pain point, SAP has introduced two specialized services designed to simplify and accelerate the process: 

  • TEST DATA CONVERSION – post-conversion accelerator 
  • TEST DATA REFRESH – Ongoing quality assurance 

 

To streamline the setup of a new test tenant, SAP offers two powerful services that cater to different data sources and testing needs: 

 TEST DATA CONVERSION Service – post-conversion accelerator 

  • Purpose: Transfers configuration and application data from the Customizing Tenant to the New Test Tenant. 
  • Goal: Ensures the new test system is available seamlessly and without issues, reflecting the latest customizing setup. 
  • Source System: Customizing Tenant 
  • Target System: New Test Tenant 

This service is ideal for scenarios where you want to validate configurations, execute test cases, test new features based on your previous customizing tenant. 

 

 TEST DATA REFRESH Service – Ongoing quality assurance 

  • Purpose: Transfers selected business data from the Production Tenant to the New Test Tenant. 
  • Goal: Ensures the new test system is populated with production-like test data, enabling realistic testing and ongoing quality assurance. 
  • Source System: Production Tenant 
  • Target System: New Test Tenant 

This service is perfect for regression testing, integration validation, and performance benchmarking using real-world data.

 

What’s Next? 

In this blog, we explored the two key services TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH that help populate a new test tenant efficiently. We also clarified the source and target systems for each service along with their roles in test tenant setup. 

In the next blog, we’ll take a deep dive into the TEST DATA CONVERSION service, examining its capabilities, process flow, and how it ensures a seamless transition from the customizing tenant to the test tenant. Stay tuned to uncover configuration tips, and real-world use cases that make TEST DATA CONVERSION a game-changer for test system readiness. 

 

Reference links: 

Blogs:
  • 3SL Conversion for two-system landscape customers managed by SAP Central Business Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL onboarding and initial system set-up series
  • Streamlining 3SL Post Conversion Steps: Introducing CIAS and TDC Services
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/test-data-refresh-service-request-on-sap-for-me/ba-p/14171893

Community Pages:

  • https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/s4hana-cloud/three-system-landscape

entry.title: Re: ROLE AUTHORIZATION PFCG
entry.content: One of the roles assigned to USER1 has authorisation object S_TABU_DIS with wide display rights. SE16 can be restricted by table (S_TABU_NAM), but also by table authorisation group (S_TABU_DIS). The check order is that if S_TABU_DIS fails, only then is S_TABU_NAM checked. S_TABU_DIS with * is a critical authorisation based on the SAP Security Baseline Template.

entry.title: Synchronizing ERP Vendor IDs and SM IDs Between SAP Ariba and Multiple ERPs
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I am currently working on an integration scenario involving SAP Ariba Supplier Management and multiple SAP ERPs via CIG (Cloud Integration Gateway), and I would like to get your expert input on the best approach to fulfill a specific client requirement.

Context and Requirement:
The customer wants to ensure that new suppliers are always created starting from SAP Ariba Network. Once a supplier is registered and qualified in Ariba, the goal is to maintain a single ERP Vendor ID and one SM ID across the landscape.

The main objectives are:

  • Avoiding double maintenance of suppliers across systems.
  • Ensuring a consistent relationship between one SM ID in Ariba and one ERP Vendor ID in the connected ERP systems.
  • Preventing a scenario where one supplier in Ariba has one SM ID but two different ERP Vendor IDs (which, to my knowledge, is not supported).

Possible Approach Considered:

  • Supplier is created in Ariba with an SM ID.
  • A temporary vendor ID (e.g., VDRxxx) is generated and routed via CIG to both ERPs.
  • At the registration approval stage, the integration to ERP 1 provides the final ERP Vendor ID.
  • The open question: Can this final ERP Vendor ID also be pushed automatically to ERP 2 via CIG so that both ERPs share the same vendor ID for the supplier?

One possible design that comes to mind would be to allow the supplier to be initially created in Ariba with its SM ID and a temporary vendor ID, for example VDRxxx. In this initial phase, the information could be routed via CIG to both ERPs. The point of uncertainty arises when the supplier reaches the stage of registration approval: if the first ERP integration returns a final ERP Vendor ID, could this same vendor ID then be pushed and synchronized also to the second ERP? In other words, is there a standard mechanism within CIG and Ariba Supplier Management to enforce the use of a single ERP Vendor ID across multiple ERPs, or would this require a different design approach?

Final Questions:

  1. Is the above scenario feasible with standard Ariba–CIG capabilities?
  2. If not, what would be the recommended best practice to ensure alignment between ERP Vendor IDs and SM IDs across multiple ERPs?
  3. Considering an architecture of 1 parent and 1 child (buying and invoicing), what is the most reliable approach to avoid duplicate supplier maintenance while maintaining consistent identifiers?

Thank you for your help and support!

entry.title: Re: How many licenses needed for SAP Adaptive Enterprise...
entry.content:
Hello Sergio

The number of licenses required would be 32. 

Please refer to https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/keys/license-key-help.html

(I had an issue with this direct link which may have to do with SAP Portal, if so use navigation
On SAP Portal, go to 'Keys' tile
Then expand Licene Key help (click on > before it)
Link to 'License Key help'
Use 'SAP Sybase' tab
There is an FAQ 'What is number of licenses'

The number of licenses to be specified depends on how many licensed units are needed for the application running on this machine. For entitlements licensed under CPU license types, the quantity should correspond to the number of processors, i.e. cores, on the machine, partition or resource-set.

Support KBA also covers this:
https://me.sap.com/notes/3143614 SYSAM core licenses requirement when hyper-threading is enabled - SAP ASE

Kind regards

Bart

entry.title: Re: How can we resend the emails from IAS
entry.content:
So in case someone is just dealing with this in the context of bulk importing via csv:
urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User:sendMail can be used as attribute in csv-file and set to true.

So deleting new users and re-importing with sendMail attribute is a way, without using manual password-reset button/mail.

Obviously, this is not quite the same context as a general resend button, and i also assume people already know. Also this should only be used for new users with no linked app-data or anything.

entry.title: Re: ABAP SALV Table with Checkbox Column, Select/Deselect All, and Email Export Functionality

Why did you code the selection yourself instead of using the standard one?

gr_table->get_selections( )->set_selection_mode( cl_salv_selections=>multiple ).

Using IF_SALV_C_SELECTION_MODE~MULTIPLE for modern selection of lines (click anywhere in the table) and IF_SALV_C_SELECTION_MODE~ROW_COLUMN for classical selection of lines (with checkboxes)

entry.title: Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
As organisations evaluate deployment options for their ERP systems, SAP Cloud ERP Private are often compared without taking the full scope of services into account. Yet, its unique architecture and comprehensive service model make direct comparisons challenging - and frequently misleading.

Traditional comparisons tend to overlook many of the embedded services that come standard with SAP Cloud ERP Private and ignore many of the available options, inadvertently giving other deployment models an apparent advantage. This not only skews perception but also obscures the full value SAP delivers out of the box.

To bring clarity to this discussion, we highlight the key services included in SAP Cloud ERP Private . Our goal is to empower customers with a clear understanding of what they receive, helping them make informed decisions based on a complete picture.

Modernise your ERP system while retaining your investment

SAP aims to transition all customers using SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA by 2027. Before the introduction of RISE with SAP in 2021, SAP did not fully meet the needs of customers seeking cloud-based ERP solutions. The primary option available was S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, which required a new implementation. This was not a viable option for many existing SAP ERP customers who wanted to retain their investment in their current systems, leverage existing data, and carry forward customizations and modifications.

To address this gap, SAP introduced SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions with the launch of RISE with SAP. These single-tenant solutions offer each customer their own dedicated instance of SAP software, hosted on separate infrastructure within a data center operated by one of the major hyperscalers or SAP itself. Existing SAP ERP customers can choose to either lift-and-shift their SAP ERP systems or transition to SAP Cloud ERP Private using a system conversion, selective data transition, or a new implementation approach.

With SAP Cloud ERP Private, SAP is taking away the complexity of designing, building and operating SAP software for our customers. We're doing this by providing a user or metric-based subscription model that includes the software and tooling license, infrastructure and technical managed services - everything that you need to run an SAP solution.

SAP Design, Build and Operate the entire SAP technical solution stack

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS), the line of business in SAP who is responsible for design, build and operate of Cloud ERP Private, delivers a robust framework for operating SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, combining infrastructure, software licensing, and technical managed services into a unified subscription model. This approach simplifies the complexity of running SAP systems in a private cloud while ensuring enterprise-grade performance, security, and compliance.

SAP ECS invests heavily in capabilities that ensure robust system design, rapid setup and delivery, and a high degree of automation for operational tasks. This section outlines the key activities performed by SAP ECS, categorized into three phases - Design, Build, and Operate.

The diagram below highlights the key cost elements covered in SAP Cloud ERP Private for the design, build and operation of SAP, while customers retain the responsibility and control of the application layer throughout the three phases. This is valid for every implementation and every time technical changes are made to the SAP system landscape, reducing technical tasks for customers so they can focus more on the business:

The SAP ERP Cloud Private service cover key cost elements for the setup and operation of SAP

The process of designing, building and operating SAP requires broad areas of technical expert competence and requires answers to many detailed technical questions necessary to make strong architecture design decisions. In SAP Cloud ERP Private, this complexity is moved away from being a customer responsibility to the responsibility of SAP and SAP will have the answers during the design, build and operate phases.

1. Design Phase

The primary goal of the Design phase activities is to define standard and configurable cloud-based architectures for SAP ERP systems that enable rapid deployment, customer choice to cater to their unique requirements and minimum manual overhead while meeting SAP’s stringent availability, Recovery Time Objective (RTO), and Recovery Point Objective (RPO), Service Level Agreements (SLAs), security and compliance standards. SAP ECS periodically reviews and refines these architectures and operational processes considering improvements in Hyperscaler infrastructure capabilities, 3rd party tools and services and SAP ECS’s own operational experience.

There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which hyperscaler building blocks to use?
  • Which virtual machine instances are the right fit and certified by SAP?
  • What is the security design?
  • How can business continuity be achieved?
  • How should the systems be monitored?
  • How can resources be effectively scaled?
  • What is the architecture design?

Key activities performed by SAP ECS as part of the Design phase:

  • Reference Architectures: SAP collaborates with hyperscalers to define scalable, secure cloud architectures using SAP best practices.
  • Security & Compliance: Network isolation, encryption, intrusion detection, and adherence to ISO/NIST standards.
  • Monitoring & Incident Response System: Proactive incident response systems and tailored architecture advisory services ensure resilience and performance.
  • Cloud Architecture & Advisory: SAP collaborates with customers to define optimal technical architecture, considering each customer’s system sizing, cloud security, networking and technical integration, and business continuity requirements. SAP and customers jointly engage in a Technical Assessment process to ensure the non-functional requirements are met in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

For every SAP ERP customer moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, an SAP advisory team which is part of ECS (SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA) which provides the above Cloud Architecture & Advisory services) or a similar partner advisory team, analyzes customer requirements and determines the best suitable configuration for the customer. By leveraging pre-defined standard and configurable cloud-based architectures defined by SAP, the time taken to define the architectures for each customer is significantly reduced and the decision process is simplified.

2. Build Phase

The primary goal of the Build phase activities is to define how to install, configure and validate the systems
that have been designed. There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which tools should be used?
  • How to ensure systems are built to provide optimal performance?
  • How to migrate existing workloads?
  • How to ensure implementation best practices are followed?
  • How to reduce the deployment time?
  • How to technically validate the new infrastructure?
  • How to ensure proper governance to manage issues?

SAP has created a global framework for the build phase that spans the multi-cloud Infrastructure ecosystem.
This framework covers best practices for migration into the cloud, automated provisioning, deployment, and
validation of SAP systems. This allows our customers to safely adopt and run new SAP software innovations
because cloud services are tested and made production-ready before they are made available to customers.

  • Datacenter facilities, physical hardware and connectivity
  • Infrastructure Provisioning: Certified compute, storage, and network components are deployed using automated tools and DevOps methodologies.
  • Technical Managed Services required to build and deliver the infrastructure
  • Software Stack: SAP installs and configures OS, databases, and ERP applications, including industry best practices.
  • Operational Tooling: Licensing and integration of provisioning, monitoring, backup, and cybersecurity tools.

3. Operate Phase

The primary goal of the operate phase is to provide ongoing support, infrastructure management, change
management and the technical services necessary to run the application. There are several complex topics
that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • How should the SLAs be measured?
  • How to manage the changes?
  • How to automate and achieve operational efficiency?
  • How to manage security incidents and threats?
  • How to keep SAP applications up-to-date?
  • How to address capacity planning?

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services accelerates and simplifies customers’ business transformation by running their SAP systems with a world-class level of availability, security and resilience, supported by an application-level SLA and a managed cloud service tailored to SAP systems. After a successful transition from the build phase to the operate phase, the ongoing support work is performed, along with additional application deployment activities. It covers the management of the installed infrastructure and applications, scaling the infrastructure, and managing ITIL processes through an engagement model with proven governance to secure business continuity.

  • Datacenter & Capacity Management: Continuous infrastructure optimization, backup integrity, and disaster recovery planning.
  • Security Operations: 24/7 threat detection, patching, vulnerability scanning, and advanced forensics.
  • Service Management: ITIL-based workflows, global support teams, and dedicated technical service managers ensure SLA adherence and business continuity.

Selecting the right deployment for your ERP system

Through SAP's Technical Assessment process, we work closely with each customer to address all questions related to the design, build, and operation of SAP in Cloud ERP Private. During this assessment, SAP provides detailed insights into the cloud service elements and explains the available options for transitioning to SAP Cloud ERP Private.

One such option is SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper, which helps customers extend support for their existing S/4HANA systems, ensuring business continuity: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper

SAP ECS empowers enterprises to move legacy ERP systems to private cloud environments without compromising control, compliance, or customisation. Our private cloud strategy serves as a blueprint for scalable, secure, and intelligent ERP modernisation.

entry.title: Re: Difference between TYPE and LIKE in ABAP – When to us...
entry.content:
Typo in your answer: the "Comparison" array has "Feature / TYPE / LIKE" outside the array.

"Always use TYPE for work areas of tables (from DDIC)" is not clear, I guess it means "Always use TYPE for referring to DDIC types" (LIKE is still permitted with DDIC types in old ABAP code).

There are other variants of DATA keyword (TYPE TABLE OF, etc.) For more information, here are the direct links to ABAP documentation (latest ABAP version): DATA ... TYPE ... versus DATA ... LIKE ..., and TYPES ... TYPE ... versus TYPES ... LIKE ....

entry.title: Re: Managed RAP and errors (FAILED) from a determination.
entry.content: My understanding is that static variables should not be used for any "state" (e.g. "determination failed"), but the state should be stored in the CDS entity (as a dummy value or in a separate field). And the guiding principle was to keep modifying operations (including determinations) apart from validations, which are then executed on data that can no longer be changed (during the CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE phase).

entry.title: GL Planning in S4 Hana Fiori Launchpad:
entry.content:
GL Planning in S4 Hana Fiori Launchpad: 

In SAP S/4HANA, GL planning is performed through the Fiori Launchpad, offering a user-friendly and intuitive interface for financial planning activities.

Steps:

Configuration that is required for GL planning in SAP S/4HANA. Plan Category needed to be created in the system through SPRO Customizing. The configuration path is shown in the attached screenshot.

Create the Plan Category exactly as shown in the configuration screenshot below.

Next, access the Fiori Launchpad by entering transaction code “/n/ui2/flp” and proceed to log in.

Then, navigate to the 'Import Financial Plan Data' tile within the Fiori Launchpad.

After selecting the tile, click on 'Download Templates' as shown in the screenshot, and download the template for 'P&L Statement Planning'.

Below is the attached GL planning template that needs to be filled out. If required, you can also add additional fields such as Profit Center and Cost Center by identifying the relevant field names from the following SAP help page: SAP Help – Financial Plan Data Fields."

Once the template is filled with the required planning data, upload it using the same 'Import Financial Plan Data' tile in the Fiori Launchpad.

After uploading the file, navigate to the 'Display Financial Plan Data' tile to review the uploaded planning information.

 

 

After selecting the tile, enter the planning parameters as shown in the attached screenshot. Additionally, activate the navigation panel from the top left corner to include more parameter-based views, such as Profit Center, if it was included in your planning data.

 

 

To analyze Plan vs Actual data, you need to activate the 'P&L - Actual/Plan' tile in Fiori. This tile allows you to compare planned and actual figures at the Financial Statement Version (FSV) level, including its individual nodes, as shown in the screenshot below.

Summary: 
GL Planning in SAP S/4HANA, enabled through the Fiori Launchpad, provides a simple yet powerful approach for financial planners. From defining a plan category to importing data and analyzing plan vs. actual figures, the process is streamlined and user-friendly. With these capabilities, organizations can achieve better control and visibility over financial planning processes.
